Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Making the Internet Safer One Website at a Time
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project will develop a novel security capability for protecting websites against hackers by providing preventive and early diagnosis services. Compromising websites is an emerging and profitable business for hackers, with devastating effects since such attacks: (a) hurt the compromised site directly, e.g. stealing stored credit card information, (b) hurt the website visitors, who are subjected to viruses infections or identity theft via code injection, which turns a legitimate website into a distributor of malware, and (c) hurt the reputation of the code-injected website, which is inevitably blacklisted by search engines. The project will develop the technology to: (a) assess the vulnerability level of a website, (b) detect security breaches in the form of code injection, and (c) expedite the recovery of a compromised website. the proposed work focuses on three key goals: (a) massive scalability through the minimization of manual intervention, (b) robustness and manageability by a carefully designed software-hardware architecture, and (c) continuous process of self-improvement and assessment of performance.

If successful, the impact of the proposed project has the potential to be immediate and direct: it promises to make website security more affordable, and not a luxury or an afterthought. Website security is an immediate and expensive problem: (a) it is estimate that most websites (over 60%) are vulnerable, (b) web-based malware spreading is taking the dimensions of a pandemic, (c) all of the reported 74M active websites are likely targets: from banks, to the local cookie store, and ultimately, (d) cyber-crime is a top national security threat according to the government. The proposed solution has the potential to make significant contributions in each of these four areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
StopTheHacker’s   niche goal is to safeguard websites and their reputation via preventive and early-diagnosis “health-care” SaaS services. StopTheHacker’s services help the 9,000+ new websites that get blacklisted on a daily basis, after they get compromised by hackers. Compromising websites is an emerging and profitable business for hackers, with devastating effects as such attacks: (a) hurt the compromised site directly, e.g. stealing stored credit card information, (b) hurt the website visitors, who are subjected to viruses infections or identity theft via code injection, as legitimate websites turn into distributors of malware, and (c) hurt the reputation of the code-injected website, which is inevitably blacklisted by search engines.

StopTheHacker  was known pre-incorporation under the name JAAL LLC.

Scientific Merit: From a technical point of view, the project has built on the core technology of Phase I, with additional capabilities and features that require significant engineering and innovation. The outcomes can be summarized in three points: (a) ensured that our monitoring technology is scaling massively, through the minimization of manual intervention, and a self-managing core infrastructure, (b) developed an automated malware recovery mechanism, to decrease recovery time, and other features requested by current customers, and (c) streamlined the integration of our service in our partners ecosystem, ie., allow hosters to integrate and resell the services in the order of minutes.  These new features have added value to customers and increase “stickiness”.

Overall, the key success of the proposal is a a web-based malware detection technology that can detect never-before seen malware accurately and scalably. As a result, the proposed technology is pushing the envelope on what is possible today in the fight against malware.

Broader Impact outcomes:

The impact of the completed phase II+IIB project is significant by adding key capabilities that make the developed commercial services easier to scale, and easier to adopt by users and web-hosters. All facts seem to indicate that web security is where anti-virus software was roughly ten years ago: initially, a novelty, ultimately, an indispensable commodity. Website security is an immediate and expensive problem: (a) most websites (over 60% ) are vulnerable, (b) web-based malware spreading is taking the dimensions of a pandemic, (c) all of the reported 150M active websites are likely targets: from banks, to the local cookie store, and ultimately, (d) cyber-crime is a top national security threat according to the government.

The proof of the success of our Phase II and Phase II-B and the validation of our technology and the opportunity for our services can be found in the market traction. Despite the limited resources for marketing and sales, we have achieved: (a) a successful series A funding  led by Runa Capital, a highly-connected Venture Capital Fund in the web hosting arena, followed by five angel investors in the San Francisco Bay Area, some with a security background, which enabled the phase II-B, (b) becoming one of the 15 platinum partners of Parallels (Parallels is the largest supplier of web hosting software, with indirect access to roughly 20 million sites), (c) over ten thousand customer accounts that are now using our services, (d) several partnerships with some of the leading web-hosting companies including Webfusion/Heart-Internet, one of the largest hosters in the UK, with an upfront payment for a 2 year contract, Softcom, a large Canadian webhoster, to name a few.
